At first, the idea of Russell Crowe playing Bill Hicks seems a really weird one. I mean, Russell's never done anything to offend me, and I really don't want him to come round and beat me up, but he's not really a clown, is he? He did one comedy film I think, A Good Year, but he didn't really pull the laughs out of the hat with that one.

Lee Mack has funny bones; Russell Crowe does not. With Russell there's too much testosterone, not enough femininity and, besides, he does that serious, middle-distance staring thing all the time.

But then that's sort of what Bill Hicks did, too. He wasn't screamingly funny. When he'd do physical comedy on stage it wouldn't really work - it was a bit awkward. He was a thinking man: an amazing comedy prophet. He was bleak, he was self-deleting, he was incredibly thoughtful but also depressive.

So maybe Russell Crowe is just right. You definitely want a proper actor to take on the part, not a comedian. You want someone with discipline, someone like Dustin Hoffman, who did a great job with Lenny Bruce.

It's a misnomer to say that comedians should play comedians - it wouldn't necessarily make things funnier. Like when you put five or six comedians on a panel show: it generally doesn't make it five or six times more funny. In all likelihood the film will be much more about what went on offstage anyway.

Still, if Russell did back out, and they wanted a comedian to play him, against my own advice I would volunteer my services. Sure, I've got a Lego haircut and I don't look like him, but I'd jump at the chance. Reginald D Hunter, too, if he weren't black he'd be great. When Reg says "I'm gonna tell you something," you sit up and listen, just like you would with Bill Hicks.

Of course they could also go down the I'm Not There route and have him played by a whole load of actors. That'd be great. And, like Cate Blanchett was, counter-intuitively, the best Bob Dylan, maybe a woman would be the best Bill Hicks. (And they could make a great point about post-feminism into the bargain!) Rhona Cameron would be perfect I think. She's got a Hicksian gait.

Labour today claimed that Boris Johnson's administration in London was "in complete disarray" following the resignation of Tim Parker as first deputy mayor.

Parker, a prominent businessman and former board member of the Audit Commission, is the third senior member of Johnson's team to quit since the former MP for Henley was elected mayor just over 100 days ago.

Parker said he was stepping down because he did not think Johnson needed a full-time first deputy mayor.

He will continue serving as an unpaid adviser. But he is also standing down as chairman of Transport for London (TfL), although he will stay on as a member of the board.

The announcement is embarrassing for Johnson because he has already lost the former deputy mayor Ray Lewis and the former deputy chief of staff James McGrath.

Hazel Blears, the communities secretary, said that the latest resignation showed that Johnson's administration was "in complete disarray", while the Labour group on the London assembly issued a statement saying Johnson was in an "unsustainable position".

Lewis resigned after allegations were made about his past, and McGrath resigned because a comment he made about black Londoners was considered open to misinterpretation.

Parker's resignation is different because it does not follow a controversy. City Hall insiders said that the move was a result of "restructuring".

But when Parker was appointed in May to be first deputy mayor and chairman of TfL, Johnson suggested that the posts would be permanent.

Today the mayor said in a statement: "Transport for London is responsible for a huge range of transport policies that impinge directly on the lives of Londoners and I was delighted when Tim Parker agreed to take charge of the board on my behalf.

"Over the last few weeks, however, it has become increasingly apparent to both of us that the nature of the decisions that need to be take are highly political and there is no substitute for me, as the directly elected mayor, being in charge. There are limits, therefore, to what can be delegated."

Parker said that he had decided it would not be appropriate for an "unelected official" to chair a body responsible for most of the mayor's spending and a large part of his job description.

Parker's statement added: "I also agree with the mayor that my position as adviser does not justify my full time and exclusive commitment to the Greater London authority, or the title of first deputy mayor. We have therefore decided to adjust the management structure and abolish that position."

Following Parker's resignation, there are four deputy mayors left, each covering a specific portfolio.

Blears said: "To lose one deputy mayor might be regarded as a misfortune, but to lose two looks like carelessness.

"People across the country, not just in London, can see for themselves that after just three months the new Tory administration in London is in complete disarray."

The Labour group on the London assembly said that Johnson's position was unsustainable because Johnson was now committed to chairing the police authority, Transport for London and the new waste authority. "He needs to find some competent deputies to share his responsibilities," the Labour group said.

Ken Livingstone, the former mayor, said: "Tim Parker was supposed to be the cornerstone of Boris Johnson's administration. His exit after just a couple of months in fact confirms the chaos which has existed in Boris Johnson's administration since day one … All this flows from Boris Johnson's incoherent policies for London and therefore incapacity to run the city.
"While some Tory sections of the press gave a glowing evaluation of Boris Johnson's first 100 days, the reality was quite different.

"This latest resignation … indicates how unfit the Tories are not only to run London but also the country."

Darren Johnson, a Green party member of the London assembly, said that Parker's departure was a result of the "rushed nature" of the mayor's appointments. "Londoners deserve a better deal from the man they have entrusted to run their city," he said.

Asked about Parker's resignation on the World at One, Johnson said that the change was mainly to do with his own need to chair Transport for London.

He said that, having studied the structure of the mayoralty, it had become clear that "it made absolutely no sense democratically for the mayor not to chair Transport for London".

Parker's resignation will not save City Hall much money because he had agreed to work as first deputy mayor for a nominal salary of £1.

A satellite the size of a double-decker bus and weighing six tonnes was launched into space early today, completing a decade-long $1.5bn (£805m) investment by London-listed communications company Inmarsat.

The Inmarsat-4 satellite, which has a solar panel wingspan the length of a football pitch, was carried into orbit by a Russian-made Proton Breeze M rocket from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

As it moves into position above the Pacific ocean over the next few weeks it will complete a global communications network for the company. There are two other Inmarsat-4 satellites in orbit.

The launch was not just a success for Inmarsat, whose shares gained 12.5p to 500.5p on the news, but for the makers of the Proton rocket at the Khrunichev plant in Moscow. The last outing of the rocket, which was developed in the 1960s to carry nuclear warheads, ended in disaster when it deployed a US communications satellite at the wrong altitude.

Despite that setback in March, which was the third in as many years, Inmarsat's chairman and chief executive, Andrew Sukawaty, said he was not overly concerned at being next in the launch queue.

"It is true that the last satellite they launched before this one was a failure but you can take that one of two ways: if you look at the history of the satellite launch business, usually the return to flight — the next one after a failure — has a very high success rate because they double check and triple check everything," he said. "We even had other satellite operators calling us and wanting to buy our slot."

The rocket blasted off at 11.43pm last night — 4.43am local time — and just over nine hours later the satellite separated from the last stage of the rocket.

The satellite will now take another four weeks to slot into its geosynchronous orbit. The first of its five solar panels is ready to begin charging the satellite's battery and the rest will follow over the next few weeks.

"But as they say in the business, 80% to 90% of the launch risk is now behind us," said Sukawaty. "We held off popping the corks from the champagne bottles until this morning."

"In fact cork separation was at 9.12am," quipped his colleague, press officer Chris McLaughlin.

The new satellite is 60 times as powerful as the whole fleet of its predecessors and can provide broadband at up to 500Kb per second. While that may seem low compared with the speed available to the average UK household, which is 10 times greater, it is a massive improvement on the current speed of just 64Kb per second.

Inmarsat supplies voice and data services to governments and shipping companies who need to keep in contact with vessels at sea, and is increasingly kitting out aircraft so that passengers can surf the internet during their flight.

Its network is also likely to be heavily used as airlines start to permit the use of mobile phones on board.

Its equipment is also used by aid agencies in remote areas.

Richard Dawkins is used to being provoked by loony American evangelical creationists. But his latest challenge comes from a strange Turkish figure called Harun Yahya whose lavishly produced (and frankly preposterous) four-volume tome The Atlas of Creation caused a stir last year when it was sent to thousands of academics across Europe.

Yahya (real name Adnan Oktar) has invited Dawkins to debate Darwin's theory of evolution with him publicly. Yahya believes the theory "has lately suffered a global collapse".

If Dawkins sincerely believes in this theory, we'd like to invite him to Turkey, or else we could come to UK to have a discussion. Dawkins should clarify hundreds of questions, only a few of which are listed below, before the cameras. So we, as well as the public, will be able to hear what he has to say.

Although coming from a Muslim rather than a Christian perspective, Yahya's approach to promoting the creationist argument will be familiar to evolutionary biologists. He selectively quotes from scientists. He claims tiny statistical probabilities that biological structures could have appeared by chance - but conveniently ignores the fact that the jump from nothing to complete structure that these probabilities imply is entirely different from the gradual changes produced by natural selection. He triumphantly cites the Piltdown Man hoax as evidence that evolutionary biologists are out to dupe us all, even though the century-old fake is irrelevant to the evidence for evolution.

He also bangs the old drum about there supposedly being no transitional fossils - there are, in fact, lots. And for some reason he has a whole website devoted to correcting the BBC.

Yahya's challenge to Dawkins continues:

Let Dawkins ask the same questions to us, and let us give our answers. Let us supply our evidence, and let him bring his - if he has any. Then let the public decide who is right. We want the public to know on a larger scale how Darwinism is a false theory and how it is the greatest deception of the world's history. We are confident that the days are soon to come when people will laugh, asking themselves "How could we ever believe this theory?"

In the Turkish courts, Yahya's organisation is currently using blasphemy laws to fight the publication of Dawkins' book The God Delusion.

"We are not against democracy, but no one can insult or defame our belief," Yahya's press assistant Seda Aral told me. She would not reveal how much money had been spent promoting The Atlas of Creation, which sells for $99 in hard copy. "We don't see the need to share this with the media," she said, although she confirmed that a "few thousand" copies of the book had been sent out.

She also denied that Yahya's organisation is supported by funding from Saudi Arabia, as has been suggested in the media, although she added, "We would be delighted to have that support."

Unfortunately for Yahya, his challenge will almost certainly come to nothing because Dawkins has vowed not to participate in such debates on the grounds that it grants undeserved scientific credibility to his opponents.

He cites advice from the late evolutionary biologist Stephen Jay Gould:

Winning is not what the creationists realistically aspire to. For them, it is sufficient that the debate happens at all. They need the publicity. We don't. To the gullible public which is their natural constituency, it is enough that their man is seen sharing a platform with a real scientist. "There must be something in creationism, or Dr So-and-So would not have agreed to debate it on equal terms." Inevitably, when you turn down the invitation you will be accused of cowardice, or of inability to defend your own beliefs. But that is better than supplying the creationists with what they crave: the oxygen of respectability in the world of real science.

Dawkins did have a spirited debate with the non-creationist Guardian columnist Madeleine Bunting.

You can also listen to Richard Dawkins on the Guardian's Science Weekly podcast.

The hiring of Associated Newspapers' commercial golden boy, Stephen Miron, one of Lord Rothermere's inner sanctum of senior management, is a stunning coup for Global Radio as it melds its business with GCap Media's radio assets.

Miron, the managing director of the Mail on Sunday and Mail Digital, has spent the best part of 17 years working for Associated and today's move has surprised the media industry.

The ebullient Miron is tipped by one industry insider to "pick radio up by the scruff of the neck" as chief executive of Global, now the UK's biggest commercial radio company following the GCap takeover, with brands including Capital, Xfm, Galaxy, Choice and Heart.

Miron, speaking about his new job, told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "It is a fantastic challenge at a very exciting company. It will be a challenge working in a new medium with a dynamic group of people."

He is one of the most highly rated, ambitious commercial operators in the UK. He reportedly turned down an offer from the ITV executive chairman, Michael Grade, to join the broadcaster's management ranks last year because he deemed the role not senior enough.

Some believe he was potentially in the running to become Lord Rothermere's right-hand man.

Inspired move

"I should think Lord Rothermere will be more surprised than anyone. There is no question that this is an inspired move by Global Radio," said one media source.

Miron was considered to be part of a small inner circle of top Rothermere lieutenants including Daily Mail managing director Guy Zitter, with whom some say he had a fractious relationship, and group managing director Kevin Beatty.

He is best known as the Associated executive behind last year's Mail on Sunday giveaway of Prince's new album, Planet Earth, which was hailed as the most successful promotion in the paper's 25-year history.

The giveaway, which fuelled an extra 600,000 sales to more than 2.8 million copies in July last year, prompted global media coverage, and anger from some music retailers, even prompting a Disney executive to describe Miron as "the most feared man in the world of content".

Miron's Prince giveaway produced the second highest sale in the paper's 25-year history, surpassed only by its September 7 1997 issue - the day after the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales.

He repeated the trick last month when a McFly giveaway boosted sales of the Mail on Sunday by about 300,000 copies.

Miron joined Associated in 1988, having previously been a sales executive at TV Times, and spent a decade in assorted roles at the Mail on Sunday.

He left in 1998 to become the commercial director at Independent Newspapers, but returned to the Associated fold after three years.

Since returning in 2002, he has worked his way up senior management ranks, having been responsible for operations including Loot, Associated's Irish operation, contract publishing and the digital business.

Groomed for the top

"The industry view was that when he came back he was being groomed for the top," said one source.

"Miron is not a man who makes impetuous decisions. He will be a bigger fish in a smaller pond at Global Radio and he can perhaps be more entrepreneurial and have more scope and influence."

Marc Mendoza, a managing partner at Havas-owned media agency MPG, said he did not believe Miron's lack of radio experience would be a problem at Global.

"Commerical nous is commercial nous and Miron is a very, very good operator," added Mendoza.

"He will bring great commercial gravitas to the organisation. He is very ambitious and he wouldn't move unless Global Radio's ambitions matched his."

Mendoza argues that Global Radio also has experts such as Don Thomson, now the chief operating officer for radio, to bolster him.

Nick Theakstone, the UK chief operating officer of WPP's combined media buying operation Group M, said: "He makes things happen - this is fantastic news for radio. They have done brilliantly to get him. He will pick radio up by the scruff of the neck."

The big question is how much Global Radio forked out to lure the one-time Safeway management trainee away from Associated.

"It is well known how well remunerated he was at [Associated]," said one source. "Global must have paid a fortune for him."

One of the biggest changes for our community, though, is the introduction of user profiles. Everybody who leaves at least one comment on our site automatically gets a user profile, which is a historical aggregation of their public participation on the site.

For a long time, we and many other sites operated a content-driven model which meant that user comments were only associated with - and displayed alongside - a particular content item. The creation of user profiles reveals our growing community-driven approach, recognising that just as every guardian.co.uk author gets a contributor page in which their contributions are archived so that their participation can be explored across topics and over time, so should our users.

The resignation of Michael Vaughan has provided breathing space for one man in particular, but we may be talking about a quick gulp rather than a lungful. If England fail to perform in their one-day games against South Africa over the next fortnight, the future as coach of Peter Moores must be called seriously into question. The Spin doesn't want to come over all red-top here: this is not a witch-hunt for the sake of it. But the evidence has been unfavourable for a while now.

Let's start with a simple comparison. When Duncan Fletcher took over for the 1999-2000 trip to South Africa, England were bottom of the world and picked a suitably shambolic touring side that included Gavin Hamilton, Darren Maddy and Chris Adams. Yet within a year England had won their first Test series against West Indies since 1969, their first in Pakistan since 1961-62 and had come from behind to win in Sri Lanka. Progress was almost immediate.

Moores may have inherited a side that had just flopped badly in Australia and the Caribbean, but at least it contained players who had grown up tasting victory as well as defeat. Fletcher did not have that luxury. Yet well over a year into Moores' reign, not even the most ingenious management speak can put a reassuring gloss on England's status in the world game, which is now best described as mid-table mediocrity, in both Tests and one-dayers.

Defeat to South Africa, who are currently ranked second in one-day cricket behind Australia, would mean England have lost three series out of four this summer. And if it's progress we're talking about, that compares badly to 2007, Moores' first year in charge, when the overall balance was 2-2 and would have been even better if an lbw decision had gone England's way in the Lord's Test against India.

Passing judgment from outside the dressing room can be perilous, but such has been the level of dissatisfaction from within it that those judgments are being dished out on a silver platter. One senior player - anonymous, of course - has been quoted as saying he finds the coach's "in your face" approach grating, and there is well-sourced speculation that suggests Vaughan might still be captain if another coach was in charge. "That'll teach them to go with statistics," he reportedly muttered during the Headingley Test, a reference to the procedure that led to the selection of Darren Pattinson (Moores is one of four selectors). Hardly inspires confidence, does it?

So what will happen if - as seems likely - England lose the five-match NatWest Series to a buoyant South African side? The chances are we'll be told that the team is in transition (with less than a year before Australia arrive), that the boys are pulling together, and that international cricket is a tough environment. And then? Then England will go to India and be thankful they're only playing a two-Test series.

In one respect Moores deserves our sympathy: there is so little talent knocking on the door that when he was asked - three times - after the Edgbaston Test who he and the other selectors had their eye on in the county game, the only name he could produce amid some painfully evasive and long-winded answers was Ravi Bopara, who is not exactly an unearthed gem.

The suspicion remains that Moores lacks Fletcher's knack of identifying players possessing the mental toughness - hence the over-reliance on stats which provoked Vaughan's grumble. But that, surely, is only part of a coach's brief, especially when the national selector, Geoff Miller, is such an assiduous watcher of domestic cricket. No, what really counts is a coach's ability to get the best out of the squad he is working with.

So far Moores has won the three Test series against sides ranked below England and lost the three against sides ranked above them. And he is in danger of sacrificing the credit built up by one-day series victories over India and in Sri Lanka. Kevin Pietersen may need to be at his electric best in the days ahead if the vultures are not to grow noisier.

All of which brings the grand total of protesters to have made it through the paperwork to the parks themselves to, umm, zero.

Perhaps NBC don't realise quite how much the Olympics can grab people's imagination. Shame they couldn't bring themselves to show Usain Bolt's incredible 100m victory, then. Shelly-Ann Fraser has put her 100m victory down to genetics, after noting how her mother was an extremely fast woman herself. Her evidence? That her mum used to regularly outsprint police when they caught her trading illegally in their Jamaican ghetto.

It's not a million miles away from tag wrestling, with teams consisting of two riders in a race run over a distance of 50km (200 laps) with intermediate sprints. Here, if you're interested, are the rules in full: The final placing will be determined by the accumulated points in the sprints, which occur every 20 laps, or by the distance according to the complete laps covered by each team. Teams having covered the same number of laps will be placed according to their accumulated points. Where there is a draw on laps and points, the place during the final sprint shall decide the final result. Sprint points will be awarded as follows: 5 points to the first team, 3 points to the second, 2 points to the third and 1 point to the fourth.

Our boy Paul Goodison starts the medal race as such a hot favourite, he's practically Australian. So long as he doesn't capsize and finish last and the Swedish boat wins, there'll be another proud Team GB!GB!GB! moment in 60 minutes or so.

4.57am: So that's the triathlons done and Great Britain still searches for its first medal. Still, we're nailed on to win everything in 2012, because THAT'S THE LAW OF THE OLYMPICS, so tune in again then. Right now, here's a round up of what's been going on in Beijing this morning; here's Kriss Akabusi's provocative Awooga in the face of Usain Bolt and here's Marina Hyde on Beijing's army of volunteers helping the running of the Games.

4.50am: Germany's Jan Frodeno wins gold in the men's triathlon. Simon Whitfield takes silver, Bevan Docherty, New Zealand, takes third. Alastair Brownlee finishes 12th, Will Clarke 14th.

4.49am: Terrific stuff from Simon Whitfield, but NO! There's the man mountain Jan Frodeno, of Germany, who thunders past the Canadian, collapses to the carpet and takes gold.

4.48am: There goes Whitfield. Gomez is done.

4.46am: Hold on, Simon Whitfield is coming back to interrupt the happy trio. Four of them for the medals, and apparently it's Whitfield with the best sprint of all of them.

4.45am: Triathlon Despite the lack of British interest (a phrase that still types itself), this is compelling. Bevan Docherty, Javier Gomez and Jan Frodeno have gone together, and it's all about their sprint finishes.

4.41am: That's the bell in the triathlon, with Javier Gomez leading the formidable-looking Frodeno of Germany, Docherty of New Zealand, and Whitfield, of Canada. Brownlee is back in seventh now.

4.39am: Call off the dancing girls. Brownlee's run has now been downgraded to "brave", which, as we now know, means futile and not medal winning. The leading five have sprinted clear and the poor mite Brownlee is running through treacle as if in a nightmare.

4.37am: Brownlee has some water, and he's tipped it on his head. The breakaway comprises Gomes, Frodeno, Brownlee and Docherty.

4.35am: Six runners in the breakaway, with Brownlee one of them. Apparently Whitfield has the sprint, the Spaniards have each other, and Brownlee missed the water station.

4.33am: The Spaniard Rana has taken over this thing, from pre-race favourite Javier Gomes. Brownlee is third, although struggling a bit now since the Spanish have taken over.

4.32am: A huge Dane named Henning has just edged into the lead from Alaistair Brownlee, although the young Brit seems unperturbed. He's a real babyface is our Brownlee, which will delight the likes of Hazel Irvine and Sue Barker, who love that kind of thing.

4.28am: Alaistair Brownlee leads the Olympic triathlon.

4.25am: I can feel big Team GB!GB!GB! stirrings here. Alastair Brownlee is officially in third place in the triathlon, and they're getting very near to the impudent Bockel and Zeebroek.

4.22am: Alex in Sydney has some parenting advice: "Having a child can help and also score you brownie points. You get to say things like, 'You go to bed love and I'll stay up and give him his late bottle when he wakes' rather than 'I'll be up in a minute dear, I want to watch men in very tight lycra'." Right now, the bulging lycra of Bockel and Zeebroek are still out in front with about a lap and a half of the running gone. The chase group, including GB!GB!GB!'s Alastair Brownlee, are about 20 seconds back.

4.18am: Bockel and Zeebroek were about 40 seconds ahead at the transition to the running, but they both look utterly spent. The better runners are in the chasing pack, apparently, which include Britain's Alastair Brownlee. The Brit has taken the lead of that chase, although the Mexican Serrano is still in third, some way up the road.

4.15am: Jumping and chucking news from Team GB: Jade Johnson has made it to the final of the long jump with her last leap of 6.61m. That puts her 11th in the 12-woman final. A threat, no doubt. Then Goldie Sayers propels the javelin past the qualifying mark and is into the final as well. Bockel and Zeebroek lead at the transition to the running in the triathlon.

4.05am: Triathlon: Apparently the Mexican Francisco Serrano isn't pulling his weight in the three-man breakaway, and Axel Zeebroek is turning round asking for him to take the lead so that him and the other rider -- Luxembourg's Dirk Bockel -- can get in his slipstream. It falls on deaf ears as Serrano sits in the middle of the three.

4am: Triathlon: There's a three-man breakaway, led by Francisco Serrano of Mexico, and also includes thrash-metal's Axel Zeebroek. Brownlee is in the chasng group, about 28 seconds back. "Perhaps you could ask readers on my behalf how their sports-watching (or Guardian-online-reading) habits changed after having a child?" wonders Charles Wool. "Wife expecting next month; occurred to me that Olympics may never be the same." Anyone?

3.57am: According to the great God Wiki," says Alex in Sydney, "in Krzygstan they still practice the illegal tradition of bride kidnapping." [Legal note: sue Wiki if this is wrong. Or Alex.] "Perhaps if kidnapping was introduced to some of the events, the plucky Krzygs could motor up the medals table." Well, they do have those league tables for serial killers (in which Team GB!GB!GB!'s is a contender), so perhaps for 2012.

3.54am: "How is GB!GB!GB! actually pronounced?" asks Peter Roy. "Is it in a deep booming voice with a pause between each GB similar to the USA, USA, USA? Or is it more a GBGBGB, similar to the robot Twiki's ramblings from the Buck Rogers series?" At the moment, it's pronounced very quietly indeed.

3.52am: The American Matt Reed, a cycling specialist, has taken the lead in the triathlon. Brownlee is still able to see them, if he looks hard, and might reckon he can catch them in the run.

3.48am: Halfway through the bike section in the triathlon, and the news is that Alastair Brownlee had a very good swim. It says a lot. The Belgian Croes is still out front.

3.45am: Emily Freeman comes through her 200m heat comfortably. She finishes second, but that's good enough. Marko Albert and Peter Croes lead in the cycling section of the triathlon, as the field stretches. Brit watch has become slightly more dispiriting. Brownlee is ninth, Clarke about 20th, Tim Done=done.

3.41am: Fire alarm news: It works.

3.37am: Triathlon: The Brownlee breakaway has been swallowed up by the main group. Tim Don, son of refereeing's Philip Don, is a minute behind the main pack and is "not 100 percent", according to his agent, who has a hotline to the Beeb's commentators. "A fire alarm test at 3:30 a.m.?" says John Senior. "That should be popular with the Guardian's neighbors." They're used to it, John. Usually it's the big Monday night muesli roast, which can get a bit rowdy.

3.34am: Alastair Brownlee started off as a runner, so there would be high hopes for Team GB! GB! GB! if he can get to the running section ahead. And just as I type that, the plucky Brit breaks away from the pack on his own on the bike and this might, might turn into something worth jingo-ing about.

3.31am: Men's triathon: The Olympic record holder, Cuba's Osleidys Menendez, is sixth in the first pool of the javelin, and she might not qualify. Jenkins of Canada still leads the triathlon, with Brownlee, the 2006 World Junior Triathlon champion, second.

3.26am: The Canadian Colin Jenkins takes the lead in the cycling leg of the triathlon, as the Guardian Towers security guard informs us that there'll be a fire alarm test in 10 minutes. "Don't worry though," he adds to four ashen faces.

3.22am: 40km on the bikes in the triathlon, and Alastair Brownlee and Frederic Belaubre attempt to elope. It doesn't last long, and they're hauled back in before they reach Gretna.

3.21am: "Baiting Kyrgyzstan is unfair on a nation suffering a chronic vowel shortage," zings Chris Wright. Meanwhile, Tim Don and Will Clarke have gone missing in the triathlon.

3.19am: There are no members of Team GB in the men's 3m springboard, so it doesn't exist as far as we're concerned. Meanwhile, Shane Reed has become the first triathlete to crawl out of the water, with Alastair Brownlee, of GB, in 11th. It's a real evolutionary moment, that, when they crawl out of the water.

3.15am: Men's triathlon You don't win a triathlon in the swimming section, I learnt while watching the women's race yesterday. But for what it's worth, Shane Reed of New Zealand is leading, from Frederic Belaubre of France and Igor Sysoev.

3.04am: Men's triathlon Suddenly everything is a go-go. The shoal of triathletes are in the water, including all the British competitors; the men's 3m springboard semi-finals have started in the diving place; and the women's javelin and long jump qualifying are underway in the Bird's Nest. One pair of (tired) eyes will do their best.

3am: Men's triathlon: Live action again, mercifully, as the men's triathlon gets started. Spain's Javier Gomez is the hot favourite; Tim Don, Alistair Brownlee and Will Clarke go for GB. It's at the Ming Tomb Reservoir, which is a spectacularly beautiful place, even on the approximate four-inch screen of this Hitachi telly.

2.54am: Having spent the majority of his career guffawing at the slightest provocation, Kriss Akabusi had the smile wiped off his face by Usain Bolt "showboating" in the 100m. Why? Let Kriss explain in his own words. Nathaniel Davis wasn't impressed: "The fact that Bolt broke the world record while not even caring about breaking the world record is anything but showboating, it is almost too humble to fathom," Nathaniel says. "For me, what made Bolt's 100m win so extraordinary and awe-inducing was not simply his speed, but his refreshingly relaxed approach to a sport that has become too technical, too inhuman. Bolt only wanted to win; I find his lack of interest in anything else inspiring."

2.50am: The women's javelin is underway in the athletics arena, the preposterously named Bird's Nest. The Czech favourite sets the early pace, with a 67.69m throw. Goldie Sayers is Great Britain's hope here, and she has her first chuck in the coming hour.

2.44am: Andrew Jolly is getting in touch with his inner Kyrgyzstan: "In the interest of harmonious Anglo-Kyrgyzstani relations, and in the (probable) absence of any Kyrgyzstan nationals following the MBM, could I be the first to point out that they only have a population of 5 million, and so their medals/population ratio is quite similar to the invincible Team GB!GB!GB!. Team Kyrgy!Kyrgy!Kyrgy! even has a nice ring to it." They call that the "population defence" to any medals table debate, I think.

2.41am: Beach volleyball: Two match points are saved, one when Misty-May Treanor flaps one into the net. But then, a hopeless serve from the Brazilian player goes straight into the net, and that's that. USA win 21-12, 21-14 to book their spot in the final.

2.39am: Beach volleyball: USA, the defending Olympic champions, are 18-12 to the good, and looking like a great bet for the final. And, eat that Sao Paulo, it's now 19-20 after a dive-smash wins one point, then a terrific block wins the second. Match point.

2.36am: Tim Maitland has emailed: "Re: 'Liu Xiang's Achilles tendon? Who cares.' While I completely understand that the current union-jack-waving frenzy has awakened those patriotic genes and made you want to tea-party-like-it's-1977... but billions do care." It was kind of a joke, Tim, but you next points are fair. "I'm not sure that the comparison is completely accurate, but you can at least get a sense of perspective by considering what the emergence of the first great black sprinters meant to the African diaspora. Liu Xiang proved that Chinese... think Greater China and beyond, rather than the Peoples' Republic... could run fast. Running fast is sexy. Running fast is modern. Running fast is a sign of the emergence of the Chinese peoples in the 21st century ... When Liu snatched the numbers off his shorts and walked away... most silently did the same ... I've been watching sport for a living for the best part of 25 years, and it was one of the most poignant moments I can remember."

2.30am: It's 10-10 in the second game of the beach volleyball. "Very disappointed to hear there will be no Aussie-baiting today," says Will Sinclair, who was in the thick of it last night, if I remember. "In it's place, can I suggest we revert to Kyrgyzstan-baiting? A quick review of the medal tally indicates that the small former Soviet state has only won a single bronze, a single silver and NO GOLD! Go back to playing your komuz (a three stringed lute, apparently), you LOSERS! Any Kyrgyzstanians care to mount a defence for their hopelessly outclassed nation?" I'm not holding out a lot of hope for this, but the challenge is there.

2.23am: Oliver Pattenden has written one very, very long sentence, and then a short one, which is a textbook set-up/punchline format if ever I saw one. Get your chuckle boxes round this: "I was about to write you a sincere email about how fed up I am with the degrading way the women's beach volleyball players (and their bikinis) are always discussed, and how it's a sport these players and their fans take very seriously, and that the comments of retrograde sexists who seem attracted purely to an article of clothing, are demoralising are not only demonstrating the pathetic level of ignorance of most sports spectators (and a fair few journalists) but are really undermining and disrespect the athletes in a way I really don't think they'd appreciate. Then I realised that Brasil's women are wearing tops with 'BRA' across their chests, which isn't really helping my point is it?" He's here all night.

2.19am: "That's it! That's it!" The first set in goes to the American duo of Kerri Walsh and Misty May-Treanor. They take it 21-12.

2.17am: I have just watched "the play of the tournament" in the beach volleyball, which has left me cold for something so magnificent. The Brazilian duo won it, and have got it back to 10-18 in the first game/set/rubber.

2.15am: Late-night stalwart Andrew Jolly (for whom it's actually the middle of the day, since he's in Australia) has been totting up what we can hope for from Team GB!GB!GB! for the rest of the games. "Laser sailing; men's madison; men's individual sprint; women's individual sprint, womens BMX, mountain bike, triple tump, and women's 400m. Have I missed anything?" Well, there's some horsey stuff, in which we're sometimes good for a bronze, and out men's triathletes have got an outside chance, apparently. That said, our outside chances in the women's event yesterday came 21st and nowhere.

2.10am: Beach volleyball: This is the women's semi-finals, by the way, between Brazil and the United States. I'm guessing it's live, in which case the score is 10-5 to USA in the first game, but it might be recorded, in which case .... USA won 2-0.

2.08am: Beach volleyball: Straight in and straight into the beach volleyball. I've never gone crazy for this, since I have previously seen bikinis before, and also have access to the internet, where there are all kinds of things to see, so I'm told. Happy that it's on today, though, because it gives me the perfect excuse to quote New Yorker writer Anthony Lane, who said: "Beach volleyball is to proper volleyball what Elvis's movies are to Elvis's music," among 5,000-odd other words on the Games that I advise you to read.

1.55am: Here we go again, here we go-go-go to the temple of consumption. It's day 11 at the Games of the XXIX Olympiad in Beijing, and it's going to be another thriller.

Over the previous 10, Her Majesty the Queen has received a huge boost to the drafting of her New Year's honours list, with a 12-gold-medal haul for Team GB. The future MBEs, CBEs, Knights and Dames of our proud nation have surpassed the expectations of even the most jingoistic cab driver. Liu Xiang's Achilles tendon? Who cares. Team GB has biked, sailed, rowed and swum the gold into our souls, and we're loving it.

Today, the fun starts with the men's triathlon at 3am BST, about an hour from now. Do two outside chances make a genuine chance? Who knows, but son-of-former-football-referee-Philip-Don Tim Don, a former World Champion, is going, as is British champion Will Clarke, whose father never officiated any top-level football match, unless you know different. Emails are always welcome. Alistair Brownlee is also wearing the Team GB colours, but he doesn't have a Wikipedia entry.

Much later, Bradley Wiggins, Mark Cavendish, Victoria Pendleton and Chris Hoy go in the velodrome, and Paul Goodison is off again in the men's laser (sailing). Bikes and boats=British bounty. On the track, Christine Ohuruogu goes in the 400m, and there also some dressage.

All kind of other events featuring athletes not from these shores will be grudgingly squeezed into the other 19 hours of this live report. Stick with us.
